DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Announces Sign-up for New Soybean Program
DOC.TEXT: Farmers can sign up in a new ``0-25'' program for 1990-crop soybeans Jan. 16 through Feb. 16, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The program will enable farmers to plant soybeans on as much as 25 percent of their permitted acreages for 1990 wheat, feed grains, cotton and rice. Sunflowers and safflowers also may be planted but will not require a formal signup. If farmers choose to participate in the new program, the acreage in soybeans will still be considered planted to the other commodities for crop history purposes, said Dan Shaw, acting vice president of the department's Commodity Credit Corp. Following the signup, the department will estimate how 1990 soybean prices may respond. If prices are indicated at less than $4.98 per bushel _ 110 percent of the price support loan rate of $4.53 _ the USDA ``will reduce or eliminate all or a portion'' of the permitted acreage than can be planted to soybeans under the program, he said. Producers can get further information from county offices of the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, Shaw said.
